verses.text: Now in those days, as the number of disciples was increasing, there arose a complaint by the Hellenists against the Hebrews, because their widows were being overlooked in the daily distribution of food.
verses.comment: The early church faced administrative challenges as it grew. The mention of 'daily distribution' refers to the practice of charitable care for the needy (see also Acts 2:45). Spiritual unity does not erase practical concerns for justice and charity.

verses.text: So the twelve summoned the whole gathering of the disciples and said, 'It is not right for us to neglect the word of God in order to serve tables.'
verses.comment: The apostles show the importance of ordered ministry, prioritizing prayer and preaching while delegating acts of service. This connects to the later structure where different ministries serve distinct roles.

verses.text: Therefore, brothers, select from among you seven men of good reputation, full of the Spirit and of wisdom, whom we may appoint over this duty.
verses.comment: The apostles institute a special ministry, requiring both spiritual and practical qualifications. This foreshadows the ongoing development of leadership and sacramental roles within the one, apostolic church.

verses.text: But we will devote ourselves to prayer and to the ministry of the word.'
verses.comment: The apostles distinguish between their specific apostolic ministry and other necessary works. Setting apart time for prayer and the Word displays the centrality of worship and teaching.

verses.text: The proposal pleased the whole group. They chose Stephen, a man full of faith and of the Holy Spirit, and also Philip, Prochorus, Nicanor, Timon, Parmenas, and Nicolas, a proselyte from Antioch.
verses.comment: All seven chosen have Greek names, showing sensitivity to the concerns of the Hellenists. This new ministry quickly becomes essential to church order. Stephen’s fullness of faith and the Spirit anticipates his later witness (Acts 7).

verses.text: They presented these men to the apostles, and after praying, they laid hands on them.
verses.comment: Laying on of hands is an ancient biblical sign of commissioning for ministry (see Num. 27:23, 1 Tim. 4:14). This formal act marks the start of a new order in the church, showing that leadership and ministry require apostolic appointment.

verses.text: The word of God continued to spread, and the number of disciples in Jerusalem increased greatly. A large number of the priests became obedient to the faith.
verses.comment: Even many Jewish priests believed, showing the gospel's fulfillment of Old Testament hopes (see Jer. 31:33). The church grows precisely when order and apostolic authority are established.

verses.text: Stephen, full of grace and power, was performing great wonders and signs among the people.
verses.comment: Not only apostles but others chosen and commissioned display signs and wonders. The Spirit empowers the church to manifest Christ’s works (see John 14:12).

verses.text: But opposition arose from some of those who belonged to the synagogue of the Freedmen, as it was called—Cyrenians, Alexandrians, and others from Cilicia and Asia. They began to argue with Stephen.
verses.comment: Religious opposition often comes from those zealous for tradition yet closed to Christ’s fulfillment of prophecy. Stephen’s bold proclamation echoes the witness of Jesus before his opponents.

verses.text: But they were unable to withstand the wisdom and the Spirit with which he spoke.
verses.comment: Stephen’s wisdom and Spirit echo Jesus’ promise that the Holy Spirit would give words and wisdom none could resist (see Luke 21:15). True authority in the church is always empowered by the Spirit.

verses.text: Then they secretly instigated men who said, 'We have heard him speak blasphemous words against Moses and against God.'
verses.comment: False witness and accusations of blasphemy parallel the charges leveled at Jesus (see Matt. 26:61). Faithful proclamation of Christ often provokes similar hostility.

verses.text: They stirred up the people, the elders, and the scribes. They seized Stephen and brought him before the Sanhedrin.
verses.comment: The pattern of persecution against the early church reflects the suffering of Christ and the prophets before him. Public opposition often leads to the deeper spread of the faith.

verses.text: They set up false witnesses who said, 'This man never stops speaking against this holy place and the law.'
verses.comment: Stephen is accused in the same way as Jesus: misrepresenting Jesus’ fulfillment and transformation of the law and temple (see Mark 14:58). The new temple is Christ’s Body, which is the church (see John 2:19-21; Eph. 1:22-23).

verses.text: For we have heard him say that this Jesus of Nazareth will destroy this place and change the customs Moses handed down to us.'
verses.comment: The charge points to Jesus’ claim to fulfill and surpass the Old Covenant (see Matt. 5:17). The new covenant brings about a transformed worship centered on Christ, established and sustained by divinely guided leadership.

verses.text: And everyone who sat in the Sanhedrin looked intently at him, and saw that his face was like the face of an angel.
verses.comment: Stephen’s shining face recalls Moses after speaking with God (see Exod. 34:29), symbolizing divine approval and the continuity of God’s revelation through his appointed messengers. Holiness visibly marks those who are faithfully united to Christ.
